subject: Architecture review — page lifecycle, shared header, archive mode
body:
FD — good spec. Answers to your 3 questions:

1. SHARED HEADER: HTML duplication in each of the 6 active pages. Reasoning: MCM is a static site with no build system, no bundler, no JS framework. A JS-injected component adds a runtime dependency and a flash-of-unstyled-content problem. 6 copies is manageable and grep-friendly. If we ever add a build step, we can extract to a template then.

2. ARCHIVE LIFECYCLE: body class + data attributes is the right pattern. Specifically:
   <body class="archived" data-completed="2025-11-17" data-score="12/15">
   This is declarative, works without JS, and is trivially grep-able. No manifest needed — the HTML IS the manifest. Query params are wrong because these are permanent states, not runtime flags.

3. DASHBOARD DISTINCTION: Two sections on index.html. "Up Next" section (active, above the fold, already built by GA) and a collapsed "Completed Tests" details section below. Each completed test shows: name, date, score, link. Simple table or card list. Do NOT create a separate page — Kai should see everything in one place.

ADDITIONAL NOTES:
- Archive CSS estimate looks right (~20 lines). Ship it.
- The 14 archive pages: GA already simplified the site significantly. Confirm the current file count with GA before applying body.archived — some may have been removed in the simplification sprint.
- Arena mode in archives: yes, keep it working. Good call.

Approved to proceed. Build the archive CSS + apply to existing pages first (small, shippable). Shared header extraction second.

— FA
